title: Pathogen diversity drives the evolution of generalist MHC-II alleles in human populations
text: To test this hypothesis, we combined data on the geographic distribution of human MHC class II alleles and prevalence of extracellular pathogens, empirical/computational estimates of epitope-binding promiscuity, and phylogenetic analyses
authors: Manczinger, Máté; Boross, Gábor; Kemény, Lajos; Müller, Viktor; Lenz, Tobias L.; Papp, Balázs; Pál, Csaba

title: Genomic analysis of codon usage shows influence of mutation pressure, natural selection, and host features on Marburg virus evolution
text: Our initial analysis indicated influence of nucleotide constraints on MARV codon usage patterns
authors: Nasrullah, Izza; Butt, Azeem M; Tahir, Shifa; Idrees, Muhammad; Tong, Yigang

title: Comparative Analysis of Transcriptional Profiles of Adult Schistosoma japonicum from Different Laboratory Animals and the Natural Host, Water Buffalo
text: Comparative genomics analysis of well characterized signaling pathways between schistosome and mammalian host indicates that schistosome genome encodes various growth factors, receptors and other critical components to regulate numerous cellular processes during tissue development and organogenesis
authors: Liu, Shuai; Zhou, Xiaosu; Piao, Xianyu; Wu, Chuang; Hou, Nan; Chen, Qijun

title: Natural selection and infectious disease in human populations
text: Population events that alter genetic diversity -including bottlenecks, expansions, splits and admixture -complicate accurate detection of selected loci
authors: Karlsson, Elinor K.; Kwiatkowski, Dominic P.; Sabeti, Pardis C.

title: Evolution of feline immunodeficiency virus in Felidae: Implications for human health and wildlife ecology
text:
Patterns of divergence describe substantial genetic differences among strains across the entire FIV genome and define monophyletic viral lineages unique to specific host species (Barr et al
Phylogenetic analyses of concatenated sequences from coding regions excluding env (6435 bp) recapitulate that FIV strains are specific to their host species
Although sharing conserved genome organization, large genetic differences exist among species-specific FIV strains
authors: Pecon-Slattery, Jill; Troyer, Jennifer L.; Johnson, Warren E.; O’Brien, Stephen J.
